articles.headline: Nicholas Winton, Rescuer of 669 Children From Holocaust, Dies at 106
articles.snippet: A London stockbroker in 1938, he rescued the youngsters from Czechoslovakia but then said nothing about his deeds for 50 years.
articles.abstract: A London stockbroker in 1938, he rescued the youngsters from Czechoslovakia but then said nothing about his deeds for 50 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nicholas Winton, a Briton who said nothing for a half-century about his role in organizing the escape of 669 mostly Jewish children from Czechoslovakia on the eve of World War II, a righteous deed like those of Oskar Schindler and Raoul Wallenberg, died on Wednesday in Maidenhead, England. He was 106.

articles.headline: Exxon Lumbers Along to Catch Up With Gay Rights
articles.snippet: After decades of resistance, the oil behemoth is taking carefully considered steps to support gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender employees.
articles.abstract: After decades of resistance, the oil behemoth is taking carefully considered steps to support gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: A day after the United States Supreme Court affirmed same-sex marriage as a right, more than 125 Exxon Mobil employees marched in the Houston L.G.B.T. Pride Celebration for the first time. They carried an Exxon banner and wore rainbow-hued Exxon T-shirts — all with the company’s approval.

articles.headline: Airlines Under Justice Dept. Investigation Over Possible Collusion
articles.snippet: The inquiry, which appears to be in its early stages, is a marked shift for a Justice Department that in November 2013 cleared the way for the merger of American Airlines and US Airways.
articles.abstract: The inquiry, which appears to be in its early stages, is a marked shift for a Justice Department that in November 2013 cleared the way for the merger of American Airlines and US Airways.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors on Wednesday said they had begun an investigation into possible collusion among the airlines to limit seating, two years after the Justice Department approved the latest in a wave of airline mergers, saying the combination would benefit consumers.

articles.headline: As More Tech Start-Ups Stay Private, So Does the Money
articles.snippet: Fledgling companies are increasingly delaying initial public offerings of stock, which can keep the risks — and rewards — limited to venture capitalists and hedge funds.
articles.abstract: Fledgling companies are increasingly delaying initial public offerings of stock, which can keep the risks — and rewards — limited to venture capitalists and hedge funds.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not long ago, if you were a young, brash technologist with a world-conquering start-up idea, there was a good chance you spent much of your waking life working toward a single business milestone: taking your company public.

articles.headline: Gerson Lehrman Seeks New Image as Investor Cashes Out
articles.snippet: The firm wants to be known as a “platform for professional learning,” reflecting an effort to recruit customers beyond Wall Street.
articles.abstract: The firm wants to be known as a “platform for professional learning,” reflecting an effort to recruit customers beyond Wall Street.
articles.lead_paragraph: After an insider trading investigation tarnished some firms that match hedge funds with industry experts, the industry’s biggest player is trying to recast its image just as an early financial backer has cashed out.

articles.headline: A Bankrupt Greece Is Struggling to Stay Afloat
articles.snippet: Any new bailout deal between the country and its creditors is likely to include harsher austerity measures based on an increasingly grim economic outlook, analysts said.
articles.abstract: Any new bailout deal between the country and its creditors is likely to include harsher austerity measures based on an increasingly grim economic outlook, analysts said.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — This is what it looks like when a country goes bankrupt.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: In Greek Debt Crisis, Mixed Messages and No Progress
articles.snippet: European leaders have been saying distinct — sometimes directly contradictory — things about whether there’s still a bailout deal on the table, and whether they want Greece to hold its referendum.
articles.abstract: European leaders have been saying distinct — sometimes directly contradictory — things about whether there’s still a bailout deal on the table, and whether they want Greece to hold its referendum.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Bewildered Greeks, not to speak of people throughout Europe and the world, could be forgiven for wondering who, if anyone, is in charge.

articles.headline: Emails Show Hillary Clinton Trying to Find Her Place
articles.snippet: The nearly 3,000 pages of emails released from Hillary Rodham Clinton’s first year as secretary of state reveal the early awkwardness of working for the man who had beaten her for the presidency.
articles.abstract: The nearly 3,000 pages of emails released from Hillary Rodham Clinton’s first year as secretary of state reveal the early awkwardness of working for the man who had beaten her for the presidency.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In December 2009, toward the end of her first year as secretary of state, Hillary Rodham Clinton agreed to a joint interview with perhaps her best-known living predecessor, Henry Kissinger.

articles.headline: U.S. Economy Adds 223,000 Jobs; Unemployment at 5.3%
articles.snippet: The unemployment rate fell to its lowest in seven years, but that was driven largely by an exodus of people from the work force.
articles.abstract: The unemployment rate fell to its lowest in seven years, but that was driven largely by an exodus of people from the work force.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not too hot, not too cold. But not, alas, just right.

articles.headline: Scott Walker’s Hard Right Turn in Iowa May Hurt Him Elsewhere
articles.snippet: To hold his position in the state before the first Republican nominating contest, the Wisconsin governor has become more conservative on marriage and immigration.
articles.abstract: To hold his position in the state before the first Republican nominating contest, the Wisconsin governor has become more conservative on marriage and immigration.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin spent months persuading influential Republicans that he alone had the impressive conservative achievements and mainstream American appeal needed to not only win the party’s nomination but also recapture the White House.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Weak Power Grids in Africa Stunt Economies and Fire Up Tempers
articles.snippet: Sub-Saharan Africa’s power generating capacity amounts to less than South Korea’s, and a quarter of it is unproductive at any given moment because of the continent’s aging infrastructure.
articles.abstract: Sub-Saharan Africa’s power generating capacity amounts to less than South Korea’s, and a quarter of it is unproductive at any given moment because of the continent’s aging infrastructure.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — In the darkened and chilly parking lot of a mall, a suburban family huddling around a shopping cart shared a snack on a Friday evening out. After finding their favorite restaurant closed because of a blackout, Buhle Ngwenya, with her two sons and two nephews, settled for meat pies from one of the few stores open in the mall.

articles.headline: BP to Pay $18.7 Billion for Deepwater Horizon Oil Spill
articles.snippet: The tentative settlement covers suits filed by Alabama, Florida, Louisiana, Mississippi and Texas, as well as the federal government.
articles.abstract: The tentative settlement covers suits filed by Alabama, Florida, Louisiana, Mississippi and Texas, as well as the federal government.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — An $18.7 billion settlement announced Thursday of all federal, state and local claims against the oil giant BP arising from the 2010 Gulf of Mexico oil spill would be the largest environmental settlement — and the largest civil settlement with any single entity — in the nation’s history, officials said Thursday.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson, John Schwartz and Richard Pérez-Peña
